item.title: IEEE 802.11
item.description: A part of the IEEE 802 standards (relating to [[technology/networking/area-networks#Local area network|LANs]]) that specifies the set of media access control and physical layer protocols for implementing [[technology/networking/wireless-transmission-medium#Wireless LAN|WLANs]].

item.title: Wi-Fi Protected Access
item.description: A brand of security algorithms developed after 2000 by the Wi-Fi Alliance to secure Wi-Fi networks. Also referred to by the TKIP standard.

item.title: Wired Equivalent Privacy
item.description: An obsolete security algorithm for 802.11 wireless networks first ratified in 1997. Suffered from several critical security issues, allowing it to be easily cracked.

item.title: Wireless transmission medium
item.description: The method of transmitting data through wireless means. Uses radio frequencies to transmit data. The most common standard in today’s world used is Wi-Fi by the Wi-Fi Alliance.

item.title: Ethernet
item.description: A [[technology/networking/wired-transmission-medium|wired transmission]] family of technologies frequently adapted for data transfer across the internet. Exists in the physical layer of the [[technology/networking/open-systems-interconnection-model|OSI model]].

item.title: Transmission medium
item.description: The method in which data is being transmitted to and from from. There are usually two classifications of transmission media:

item.title: Twisted pair cable
item.description: A type of wiring used in communications in which two conductors of a single circuit are twisted together for the purposes of improving electromagnetic compatibility.

item.title: Application layer
item.description: The fourth layer in the [[technology/networking/internet-protocol-suite|internet protocol suite]] and seventh layer in the [[technology/networking/open-systems-interconnection-model|OSI model]]. TCP/IP protocol suite In the context of the TCP/IP suite, the application layer provides services to users’ applications.

item.title: User Datagram Protocol
item.description: A connectionless protocol under the [[technology/networking/transport-layer|transport layer of the internet protocol suite]]. Starts data transfers without establishing a connection and is therefore less reliable but simple with low overhead.

item.title: Transmission Control Protocol
item.description: A connection-oriented protocol under the [[technology/networking/transport-layer|transport layer of the internet protocol suite]]. Connections made by the TCP are established prior to data transfer, maintained throughout the data exchange, and then terminated at the end of the communication.

item.title: Transport layer
item.description: The third layer in the [[technology/networking/internet-protocol-suite|internet protocol suite]]. Mainly used to provide end-to-end communication services for applications and is more focused on connection-oriented communications.

item.title: Internet Protocol
item.description: A network layer communications protocol in the [[technology/networking/internet-protocol-suite]] for relaying datagrams across network boundaries. Provides a packet delivery service between end hosts, also known as routing.

item.title: Internet protocol suite
item.description: A framework for organising the set of communication protocols used in the internet and similar networks. Also commonly known as the [[technology/networking/transmission-control-protocol|TCP]]/[[technology/networking/internet-protocol|IP]] protocol suite.

item.title: Address Resolution Protocol
item.description: Used to discover the [[media-access-control-address|MAC address]] of a device given its [[technology/networking/internet-protocol-address|IP address]]. There are particularly two parts to the ARP protocol, namely the request and response.

item.title: Network address translation
item.description: A method of mapping an [[technology/networking/internet-protocol-address|IP address]] into another by modifying address information in the IP header of packets while in transit across a traffic routing device.

item.title: Internet layer
item.description: The second layer in the [[technology/networking/internet-protocol-suite|internet protocol suite]]. Mainly responsible for packet forwarding, including routing through intermediate routers. Several protocols employed in the internet layer include:

item.title: Open Systems Interconnection model
item.description: A conceptual model that provides the common basis for the coordination of standards proposed by the International Organisation for Standardisation for the purpose of systems interconnection.

item.title: Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol
item.description: A protocol typically employed in the provision and assignment of [[technology/networking/internet-protocol-address|IP addresses]]. It allows a host to obtain an IP address dynamically without the network administrator having to set up an individual profile for the host.

item.title: Internet Protocol address
item.description: An identifier for a network device typically assigned by another more prominent network device that identifies the device in the network using the [[technology/networking/internet-protocol|internet protocol]].

item.title: Wired transmission medium
item.description: The method of transmitting data through physical means. Is ubiquitous even in today’s world, owing to their performance in transmitting data compared to wireless transmission media.

item.title: Network organisation
item.description: A network can differ in terms of the roles each device plays in the network. Generally, devices in a network can take up any of two roles:

item.title: Residential gateway
item.description: A network device often used in home and small office networks that combines the [[technology/networking/network-router|router]], [[technology/networking/network-switch-and-bridge|switch]], and [[technology/networking/wireless-access-point|wireless access point]]. Also usually comes with two software components: [[technology/networking/dynamic-host-configuration-protocol|DHCP]] and [[network-address-translation|NAT]].

item.title: Network hub
item.description: A network device that connects multiple devices to the same network and transmits received packets to all connected devices, regardless of which device the packet is intended for.

item.title: Wireless access point
item.description: A network device that provides a connection between wireless devices up to 100 metres away. Usually connects to wired networks and supplies a wireless network.

item.title: Modem
item.description: A network device often used in long-range networks to extend the range of the transmission of data. The term is a portmanteau of modulator-demodulator.

item.title: Network router
item.description: A network device that receives and forwards data between separate networks using Internet protocols.

item.title: Network Interface Controller
item.description: A network device built or inserted into end-user devices that provides LAN connectivity to the device. Often comes in the form of a card that can be installed, an external USB adapter, or being built into the motherboard.

item.title: Area networks
item.description: When talking about networking, there are three kinds of area networks that are of importance. They include the: local area network; metropolitan area network; and wide area network.

item.title: Network switch and bridge
item.description: A network device that constructs a single network and provides connection points to all network-enabled devices to form a local area network.

item.title: Network
item.description: The connection of at least two computer systems either by a cable or wireless connection. In today’s context, the internet is the world’s largest network (literally spelling out inter network) that connects devices across the world.
